content:
On 4 March 2025, Burnley Borough Council's Full Council approved a 2.5% backdated increase to the basic councillor allowance for 2024/25, taking it from £4,061.77 to £4,163.31. Special Responsibility Allowances (SRAs) were frozen. The allowance was then frozen at this level for 2025/26.

The Independent Remuneration Panel (IRP) had originally recommended increases of 2.5% for 2024/25, followed by 3% in each of 2025/26 and 2026/27 - a total increase of approximately 8.5% over three years. The council's ruling Executive proposed a partial freeze, accepting the 2.5% backdated increase but rejecting further rises.

Burnley's Allowance History: Steady Increases Under Previous Administrations

The basic councillor allowance at Burnley Borough Council has risen consistently in recent years:

  • 2021/22: £3,587.84
  • 2022/23: £3,732.36 (+4.03%)
  • 2023/24: £3,883.15 (+4.04%)
  • 2024/25: £4,061.77 initially, then £4,163.31 after the backdated 2.5% increase
  • 2025/26: £4,163.31 (frozen)

In both February 2023 and February 2024, the Labour group - led by Cllr Mark Townsend - voted in favour of the budgets that included councillor allowance increases of 4.04% and 4.6% respectively. The Conservative group voted against the 2023 increase.

Lancashire County Council: Reform UK Leads Unanimous Freeze

The contrast with Lancashire County Council is striking. On 17 October 2025, LCC's Full Council voted to reject all IRP-recommended allowance increases - freezing the basic allowance at £14,301 and all Special Responsibility Allowances at their existing levels.

The motion was proposed by Cllr Ged Mirfin, Cabinet Member for Resources, HR and Property. The vote passed 75 in favour, 0 against, with 3 abstentions (the three Liberal Democrat members abstained, arguing the IRP's independent recommendations should be respected).

The IRP had recommended a 3.2% increase to the basic allowance (from £14,301 to £14,759), increases to all SRAs, and the introduction of a new £1,000 allowance for opposition members. All of these were rejected.

The decision saved Lancashire taxpayers an estimated £92,000 to £115,000, depending on whether the rejected opposition member SRA is included.

Key Quotes from the LCC Debate

Cllr Ged Mirfin told the meeting the Reform group had "agreed to reject all of the proposed increases," citing "incredibly straitened times" and "an expectation from the general public" for councillors to show restraint.

Council Leader Cllr Stephen Atkinson said the refusal would save money "for the benefit of Lancashire residents," calling it "the right thing to do given the current economic climate."

Cllr Matthew Salter, Cabinet Member for Education, criticised previous councillors for "insulating themselves" from savings, adding: "When the people of Lancashire voted for Reform, they voted for change."

Cllr Tom Pickup, then Lead Member for Finance and Resources at LCC, referenced the vote when making the case for the freeze. He pointed out that Cllr Mark Townsend - who had publicly claimed on Facebook that Reform UK councillors were set to give themselves a pay increase - had himself voted to increase his own councillor allowance at Burnley Borough Council in the 12 months prior. The claim was incorrect: Reform UK councillors voted unanimously to freeze their pay.

The Facebook Claim

In the lead-up to the LCC vote, Cllr Mark Townsend, Leader of the Labour group on Burnley Borough Council, posted on Facebook claiming that Reform UK councillors at Lancashire County Council were set to give themselves a pay increase.

This claim was factually incorrect. When the Full Council meeting took place the following day, Reform UK proposed and led the motion to reject all allowance increases, which passed with no votes against.

The irony was not lost on those present. Cllr Townsend's own voting record at Burnley Borough Council shows he voted in favour of councillor allowance increases in both 2023 (4.04%) and 2024 (4.6%). At the March 2025 Full Council meeting, readers of the Burnley Express described Townsend as appearing "more interested in whether the councillor allowance was fair or not, than the extra strain the council is putting on people."

The Numbers Compared

Council IRP Recommendation Decision Saving
Lancashire County Council 3.2% increase Complete freeze (75-0-3) £92,000–£115,000
Burnley Borough Council 2.5% + 3% + 3% 2.5% accepted (backdated), then frozen £27,685 vs full IRP

What This Means for Residents

The total annual allowances bill at Lancashire County Council is approximately £1.78 million for 84 councillors. At Burnley Borough Council, the allowances budget for 2025/26 is £250,713 for 45 councillors.

While Burnley's ruling Executive deserves credit for partially freezing allowances for 2025/26, this followed two consecutive years of above-inflation increases that were supported by the Labour group. At county level, the Reform UK administration took a harder line - rejecting all recommended increases outright and saving the full amount for taxpayers.

This raises questions about the accuracy of claims made on social media by elected representatives. When a councillor publicly accuses another party of planning to increase their own pay - only for that party to then lead a unanimous vote to freeze it - residents are entitled to ask whether they are being given the full picture.

Sources: Burnley Borough Council Full Council minutes, 4 March 2025; Lancashire County Council Full Council agenda and minutes, 17 October 2025; Independent Remuneration Panel reports; Burnley Express reporting; Lancashire Evening Post.
